Gretchen_Peters:
{{short description|American musician (born 1957)}} {{distinguish|Gretchen Peters (journalist)}} {{BLP sources |date=March 2009}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Gretchen Peters | image = GretchenPeters SadSongsMakeMeHappy.jpg | image_size = 250 | landscape = yes | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|11|14}} | birth_place = [[Bronxville, New York]], U.S. | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Country folk]] * [[Americana (music)|Americana]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Singer * songwriter }} | instrument = {{flatlist| * Guitar * piano * vocals }} | years_active = 1996–present | label = {{flatlist| * [[Imprint Records|Imprint]] * Purple Crayon * Scarlet Letter }} | spouse = {{marriage|Barry Walsh|2011}} | website = {{URL|www.gretchenpeters.com}} }} '''Gretchen Peters''' is an American singer and songwriter. ==Early life== Peters was born in [[Bronxville, New York]] on November 14, 1957. She wrote her first song with her sister at the age of 5. In 1970, her parents broke up, and Peters moved with her mother to [[Boulder, Colorado]]. ==Music career== In Boulder, she discovered a lively music scene, and began playing at local clubs. In 1988 she moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], where she found work as a songwriter, composing hits for [[Martina McBride]], [[Etta James]], [[Trisha Yearwood]], [[Patty Loveless]], [[George Strait]], [[Anne Murray]], [[Shania Twain]], [[Neil Diamond]] and co-writing songs with [[Bryan Adams]].[https://www.allmusic.com/artist/gretchen-peters-mn0000197165/biography] Biography at Allmusic.com, Retrieved May 10, 2023.{{YouTube|3ke4uGjK2dU}} Some of Peters' notable compositions include "[[The Secret of Life (song)|The Secret of Life]]", "[[On a Bus to St. Cloud]]", "[[You Don't Even Know Who I Am]]" and "[[Independence Day (Martina McBride song)|Independence Day]]", for which she received the [[Country Music Association Award for Song of the Year]]. In addition, Peters has released fourteen studio albums of her own, beginning with 1996's ''[[The Secret of Life (album)|The Secret of Life]]''. As a writer, Peters' style is defined by melancholy lyrics and dark themes, such as murder, loneliness, PTSD, sexual abuse, domestic violence. She was inducted to the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] on October 5, 2014.[http://www.nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com/2014/nashville-songwriters-hall-of-fame-inducts-john-anderson,-paul-craft,-tom-douglas-and-gretchen-peters-nsai-presents-annual-awards.aspx ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024070704/http://www.nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com/2014/nashville-songwriters-hall-of-fame-inducts-john-anderson%2C-paul-craft%2C-tom-douglas-and-gretchen-peters-nsai-presents-annual-awards.aspx |date=October 24, 2014 }} On August 12, 2022, Peters announced her intention to retire from touring, playing her final shows in June 2023, though she will continue to write and record.{{cite web| publisher=Gretchen Peters| url=https://www.gretchenpeters.com/2022/08/an-announcement/ | title=News: An announcement | date=August 12, 2022| accessdate=August 8, 2024}} ==Personal life== Peters is married to keyboardist and producer [[Barry Walsh]], her long-time performing partner, who has also performed with the reunified [[The Box Tops|Box Tops]].{{cite web| publisher=Gretchen Peters| title=Gretchen Peters| url=https://gretchenpeters.com/| accessdate=August 8, 2024}}{{cite web| publisher=Barry Walsh| title=Bio - Silecio| date=2023| url=https://barrywalshmusic.com/bio| accessdate=August 8, 2024}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details !| Peak positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! style="width:60px;"| [[UK Albums Chart|UK]]
